key_points: Use-of-force expert Barry Brodd testified that Derek Chauvin was justified in kneeling on George Floyd and did not use deadly force.
Brodd argued that the "prone control" position was not a use of force because, in his view, it does not cause pain.
During cross-examination, Brodd admitted that Chauvin's knee on Floyd's neck, as shown in a photo, could be considered a use of force.
The defense's arguments emphasize that Floyd's death was due to drug and health problems, and that Chauvin's actions were appropriate.
The prosecution rested its case after calling 38 witnesses over 11 days, focusing on Chauvin's excessive and unreasonable force.
Floyd's brother, Philonise Floyd, emotionally testified about George Floyd's character and their relationship.
Brodd's testimony contradicted other policing experts and Minneapolis Police Chief Medaria Arradondo, who criticized Chauvin's actions.
The defense also highlighted Floyd's 2019 arrest and drug use to argue his death was due to health issues.
Retired Minneapolis Police officer Scott Creighton and retired paramedic Michelle Moseng testified about Floyd's 2019 arrest.
Shawanda Hill, Floyd's friend, testified about Floyd's state shortly before his arrest on May 25, 2020.
